Award.AbstractNarration:
Under this award, the principal investigator plans to continue his work in geometric partial differential equations. In particular he will investigate the role of level sets of solutions of differential equations. Special cases of level sets are given by the nodal sets, the singular sets and the branch sets. An important part of the study is the investigation of the asymptotic behavior of solutions near these sets or the asymptotic behavior of these sets themselves. The differential equations may be elliptic, hyperbolic or of mixed type. Some problems have close connections with other fields in mathematics, including several complex variables and algebraic geometry. Another class of problems that the PI will continue to work on involves the effect of level sets of known functions in the equations on the existence and properties of solutions. A particular problem is the isometric embedding of 2-dim Riemannian manifolds in 3-space when the zero set of Gauss curvature is well behaved. This problem is in the form of degenerate Monge-Ampere equations.

The problems involving nodal sets or the singular sets originate from materials science and control theory. Singular sets, as the name suggests, are those sets where singularities occur. Precise definitions vary depending on the problems where they arise. It often is impossible to eliminate the singular sets, the so-called "bad sets". One of the central tasks is to identify the conditions under which the singular sets can be controlled and the conditions under which the singular sets are small. The proposed problems concerning singular sets in the project are in their simplest forms. They are related to the Erickson's model for liquid crystals and the Ginzburg-Landau equation in the superconductivity. The PI believes that the discussion of these mathematical problems will help scientists work with singular sets in various applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Partial differential equation is an important subject in mathematics. The fundamental problem is the study of the existence and properties of solutions. The development of partial differential equations has influenced the development of other fields such as Riemannian and complex geometry and general relativity. The PI's research has been greatly influenced by problems and techniques in Riemannian geometry and complex geometry. The study of partial differential equations in a geometric setting has provided interesting new questions with fresh insight to old problems. The problems addressed in this award involve partial differential equations of various types, elliptic, hyperbolic and of mixed type, and in particular, degenerate partial differential equations. Some problems have close connections with other fields in mathematics, including complex geometry and general relativity. Due to the complexity of the degeneracy, there has been no general theory for degenerate partial differential equations. The problems proposed and studied in this award are related to some important classes of degenerate partial differential equations. Their solution advances our knowledge in all the aforementioned areas.

Broader Impacts: The work related to the award has broader impact in a variety of disciplines. The PI is engaged in the development of a textbook in degenerate partial differential equations. His goal is to make this interesting topic more accessible to a wide range of analysts and geometers. The research results are parts of the new material in the lecture notes. The PI has close interactions with Ph.D. students and post-docs. He also engages in international and interdisciplinary collaboration that brings new perspectives to the field. He co-organized several international conferences on the subject with emphasis on cross-field interactions. The PI believes that mathematicians need a strong community and views training and nurturing future analysts and geometers a top priority. He considers his teaching and mentoring activities most important and rewarding.
